Title:
Caveats of the internal transcribed spacer region as a
barcode to resolve species boundaries in Diaporthe
Keywords:
Phomopsis, DNA barcode, hybridization, ITS polymorphisms,
phylogeny
Abstract:
Species in Diaporthe are largely reported as important
plant pathogens. Identification of species in this genus has been
complemented by morphological and molecular features. However, one
important factor delaying this process is the struggle to formulate
robust species concepts to create adequate international phytosanitary
measures. Regardless of the wide use of the internal transcribed spacer
(ITS) region, established as the primary genetic barcode for fungi, the
tendency for intraspecific variation has been reported, misleading
interpretation of the phylogenetic analyses. Therefore, the present
study aimed to illustrate, using specific examples, how the ITS region
may be problematic for species delimitation. We showed that the ITS
region is highly variable, with strains of D. malorum and D. novem
falling into more than one clade, which if analyzed on their own, would
be likely recognized as distinct taxa. Divergent ITS paralogs were also
proved to coexist within the genome of D. novem. We also suggest that
ITS may have escaped from concerted evolution or has undergone a recent
speciation event. Furthermore, this study reports for the first time the
existence of a putative hybrid in the genus Diaporthe. Our findings
offer new clues towards the intraspecific and intragenomic variation in
the ITS region, raising questions about its value for barcoding to
delineate species in the genus Diaporthe. Therefore, we suggest that the
ITS region must be analyzed cautiously and always compared for
congruence prior to description of novel taxa.
